Cloud Approach for IoT based
Street Lighting System
Rui Chen, Mohamed Doray, Laura Slocum, and Sophie Su
Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
University of Kansas
Lawrence, Kansas, USA
Abstract—With an increasing level of urbanization in
most countries, there is a higher demand for street
lights to increase the sense of safety and help with
economic development in cities. Street lights are also
known to provide traffic safety by enhancing road
visibility. However, current systems are incapable to
meet the demand with high redundancy, ineffective
setup, and unreliable services throughout the street
light lifecycle. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a
centralized management system through cloud
implementation alongside IoT devices to effectively
manage the system in an automatic manner.
I. INTRODUCTION
Across the world, street lighting has long played
an important role in the city. Streetlights illuminate
highways, intersections, and street corners improving
residential safety with increased visibility
discouraging public violence. Which in turn, have a
positive economic impact. Small businesses are given
the opportunity to stay open later in areas, while
consumers are willing to pay their visit to local
businesses after dark. However, areas with decreased
streetlight coverage are shown to have a direct impact
on weather-related traffic accidents, especially in
urban areas that experience low visibility from fog
and pollution. Therefore, we are motivated to develop
data-centric smart LED street light systems to
identify and cover blind areas for hazard climate,
responding to poor conditions such as foggy, rainy,
and snowy weather that are vulnerable to traffic
accidents due to low visibility. Nevertheless, street
lights are associated with high operational costs
because the majority of the system highly relies on a
manual operation that is inefficient and wastes a lot
of energy. In our paper, we will introduce a smart
and efficient way to operate street lights by
leveraging technological advancements to lower the
cost of IoT through the centralized network. In the
emergence of interconnected network devices, the
Internet of Things (IoT) has been widely adopted in
applications. For example, security surveillance
systems, RFID tag identification, industrial sensor,,
smart homes, military applications, healthcare, and
environmental management.
The existing street light system is facing the
following issues:
a. Lack of information about the real-time
status of the street lights and area.
b. Lack of proper system for monitoring and
operating lights ON/OFF schedule.
c. Lack of a system to optimize the efficiency
of a street light system as per requirement.
d. Managing the independent unit of street
light in terms of turning ON/OFF, fault
detection & replacement.
Our proposed street light system aims to address
existing challenges to better regulate a smart city by
utlizing sensors to capture environmental and
electrical parameters related to atmosphere humidity,
temperature, particle concentration, and light voltage
to be managed through a centralized cloud server.
The proposed smart street lighting system composes
of three layers - sensor layer, layer, and management
layer [4]. These layers work together to provide an
energy-efficient smart lighting system. By means, the
sensor layer is implemented on light nodes to gather
information about the physical environment, events
are triggered by external factors like sunlight, motion,
sound, etc. This layer collects information about the
environment and passes it onto the data layer. The
data consist of a centralized cloud server to collect
from various sensors implemented across the city. By
appropriately implementing a communication
channel, the system talks to the gateways using
various communication protocols, the gateway would
forward the data to the central management system
for further processing. The management layer is
responsible analyzes and displaying data in visualized
manner. Together with a user interface to control
streetlight statuses such as scheduled ON/OFF time,
damage tracking, and light brightness ensuring
efficient management of the street light system.
The rest of the paper is divided into 3 sections.
Section 2 provides a systematic analysis of IoT to
provide readers with a solid foundation before diving
into our system. Section 3, we discuss our proposed
solution for implementing a smart street light system.
Section 4, we review the cloud implementation aspect
of our solution. Lastly, we end the article with a
conclusion section that captures the key objectives
and of the article.
II. SYSTEMATIC ANALYSIS OF IOT
Internet of Things (IoT) techniques are becoming
increasingly popular, extending high influential
computing trends that shaped our technology today.
In general, IoT is a network that contains a number of
physical devices which are allowed to communicate
with each other. IoT allows remote sensing and
controlling all IoT devices connected to it with an
IoT application. We discuss basic principles within
IoT systems in the following section, including its
relation to system layers, communication protocols,
and requirements necessary to maintain system
security.
IoT applications are used in many industries such
as healthcare, agriculture, retail, and childcare. These
applications monitor and control energy usage and
switch devices to low power or no power modes
when they are not in use. For example, Nest’s
home/away system knows when no one is home and
can turn lights off, adjust the thermostat, and turn on
security cameras. This paper will outline how this
technology can be utilized to control city
infrastructure systems such as street lighting.
An IoT device is made up of four main
components: hardware, cloud, network, and software.
Hardware includes all physical devices which are
embedded with sensors, actuators, gadgets,
applications, or machines, and can communicate with
each other over the internet. The physical devices in
IoT systems collect different types of data and send it
to the cloud through a network. The network can
transmit data between devices, cloud, and IoT
applications. The cloud is a back-end system that
stores and processes the data collected by the devices
and serves the software that controls the device.
Software is a cloud-based application that
communicates with the cloud and provides a user
interface to allow users to manage and control all IoT
devices connected to it.
In our IoT-based street lighting system, the sensor
layer is the hardware that contains the devices with
sensors to gather physical environment information.
The gateway in the communication layer is the
network that can send the information to the
management layer with a communication protocol.
The management layer contains both cloud and
software to process the data and control the street
light devices in the sensor layer.
A. IoT Communication Protocols
IoT protocols and standards are broadly classified
into two separate categories: IoT data protocols and
IoT network protocols.
IoT data protocols are used to connect low-power
IoT devices and provide communication with
hardware on the user side. These types of protocols
operate at presentation and application layers.
Following are some examples of commonly used IoT
data protocols:
CoAP (Constrained Application Protocol): A
CoAP is an application layer protocol that is designed
to address the needs of HTTP-based IoT systems.
CoAP relies on the User Datagram Protocol (UDP)
for establishing secure communication between
endpoints and adopts the basic HTTP GET, POST,
PUT and DELETE message types to request
resources from the server.
MQTT (Message Queuing Telemetry Transport):
MQTT is a lightweight M2M communication
protocol for constraints and unreliable networks. It
features a publisher-subscriber messaging model that
works on top of TCP/IP protocol and allows for
simple data flow between different devices.
AMQP (Advanced Message Queuing Protocol):
An AMQP is an open standard application layer
protocol used for transactional messages between
servers. Like MQTT, this protocol uses a
publish/subscribe mechanism for the transmission of
data to provide reliable communication and
guarantees message delivery.
IoT network protocols, which are used to connect
devices over a network, and utilize many traditional
networking protocols operating at physical and data
link layers. IoT network protocols can be categorized
into two categories: short-range network and Low
Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) which is
designed for wide-area coverage and provide
excellent signal propagation to hard-to-reach indoor
places. Some commonly used IoT network protocols
are described below:
ZigBee: ZigBee protocol is created based on
low-power wireless IEEE802.15.4 networks standard
for wireless personal area networks. It is
characterized by low power consumption, low
throughputs, and a connectivity range of 100 meters
between nodes.
6LoWPAN: IPv6 over Low power Wireless
Personal Area Networks (6LoWPAN) is an IP-based
standard internetworking protocol used for
short-range networks. In order to manage
compatibility between IEEE 802.15.4 and IPv6,
6LoWPAN offers an adaptation layer between the
MAC layer and the network layer (IPv6)
Z-Wave: This is a low-power MAC protocol that
uses wireless home automation to connect 30-50
nodes. However, like ZigBee, Z-Wave is primarily
used for IoT home applications and not be used
within the business world.
SigFox: A low power protocol for wireless
communication of different types of low energy
objects such as sensors and Machine-to-Machine
(M2M) applications. It is used for LPWAN with a
range of up to 50 kilometers for the transportation of
a small amount of data.
LoRaWAN: This is a physical layer media access
control (MAC) IoT protocol that allows low-powered
devices to communicate directly with
internet-connected applications over a long-range
wireless connection. Moreover, it has the capability
to be mapped to both the 2nd and 3rd layers of the
OSI model.
B. IoT Security
As discussed in IoT systems, an IoT system can
be divided into four layers: sensing (hardware) layer,
cloud layer, network layer, and application (software)
layer. Each of these layers are using different
technologies that may cause some issues and security
problems. This section will briefly discuss the
security threats in each layer of the IoT system.
a. Sensing Layer: The sensing layer mainly
deals with physical IoT sensors and
actuators which communicate with each
other and gather various kinds of data. Thus,
major security threats such as node
capturing, malicious code injection attacks,
false data injection attacks, and side-channel
attacks can be encountered at the sensing
layer.
b. Network Layer: The key function of the
network layer is transmitting the information
received from the sensing layer to the cloud
layer for processing. Some security issues
like phishing site attacks, access attacks,
DDoS/DoS attacks, data transit attacks, and
routing attacks can be encountered at this
layer.
c. Cloud layer: This layer is mainly used for
data processing and communicating with the
sensing layer and application layer. It is the
core system of the IoT system. In this layer,
a Man-in-the-Middle attack, SQL injection
attack, and cloud malware injection attack
can be encountered.
d. Application layer: The application layer
directly deals with and provides services to
the end-users. This layer has specific
security issues that are not present in other
layers, such as access control attacks,
service interruption attacks, sniffing attacks,
and reprogram attacks.
To mitigate the security issues for IoT systems,
some technology can be applied such as data
encryption, Blockchain, fog computation, edge
computing, and using Machine Learning techniques.
III. PROPOSED SOLUTION
In this section, we formalize the design goal by
examining the system model and security
requirements for the proposed cloud centralized street
light management system. The use case of our system
can be industrial, community, or city network
consisting of street lights within the area. In the
system model, we mainly focus on acquiring data
visibility and maintainability throughout the life cycle
of street lights. The system consists of the following
units with a description of their usage in the system:
1) LDR Sensor: Also known as a light-sensitive
device to capture the intensity of light as
well as the presence or absence of light.
LDR sensors are installed on street light
areas in our system, responsible for
capturing the daylight within 24hr
timeframe for the system to determine
brightness level for the streetlight at given a
given time.
2) Temperature Sensor: An electronic device to
measure the temperature of the environment
and computers to digital data for record,
monitor, and calculation purposes.
3) Humidity Sensor: Capture the moisture of
the surrounding environment for
computation of voltage level needed to
maintain light brightness.
4) Infrared Sensor: The instrument used to
capture characteristical change by its
environment such that detection of human
heat may trigger the switch of street lights
for a specified time.
5) Closed Circuit Television Camera: Working
alongside infrared sensors in the detection of
environmental change, such as approaching
automobiles in the distance that triggers the
switch of street light for a specified time. It
may also be used to record suspicious
persons or behavior.
6) Microcontroller: A free-standing system
with memory and programmable
input/output peripherals embedded in
streetlights to process and forward captured
streetlight data onto cloud data storage.
7) Ethernet & Routers: Digital Local Area
Network (LAN) to enable internet
transmission supporting communication
between streetlight controller and a central
server.
8) Trusted Server: The virtual infrastructure
that performs application processing and
data storage provided by a trusted party such
as Google Cloud, AWS, or Azure.
Assuming the internal communication among IoT
devices are secure, communication channels should
be established using standard security protocols under
WirelessHART. A widely used, cost-effective, and
scalable interface to support secure gateway
transmission among network participants. Our design
goal is to enable systematic control for street light
adaptation to the ever-changing weather conditions.
The street light embedded microcontroller is designed
to periodically collect and forward its environmental
information to the cloud server. The application
implemented on the cloud server interprets the data,
computes the data against threshold values to
determine streetlight performances. For example, a
streetlight brightness level at a given time is set to be
x, if the captured data (voltage, brightness, time of
the day ) did not meet the acceptable range of the
given threshold. It could potentially indicate
streetlight malfunctioning, requiring on-premise
inspection. Otherwise, data are forwarded onto the
application layer for management purposes. Feature
of the management application includes the following
features:
● Data Visualization, plotting the data to show
the performances of street lights such as
voltage consumption, brightness
requirement, and maintenances need
responding to malfunctioning lights by
locating light locations on the map.
● Brightness Control, the application gathers
sensor information to calculate the
brightness level needed to maintain road
visibility. Forwards back to adjust the
voltage level of street lights needed to
maintain the calculated brightness.
● Voltage Control, controller interface queries
back onto streetlight for output voltage
regulation, functions to adjust transmission
magnitude as needed.
● Scheduling, based on the time of year, an
administrator is able to set a schedule for
brightness and when street lights should be
ON/OFF.
Monitored through the application dashboard,
administrators are able to acquire real-time indicators
of street light performances. Ideally, the city
administration is responsible for establishing a
schedule prior to events for when all street lights are
turned on, taking into account criteria such as the
time of year, traffic load, and population density.
Eventually, the control portal saves the schedule for
future execution through network queries,
commanding the street light controller to modify
voltage output as needed. In the proposed setup, city
lights gain access to low-cost, low-power sensor
technology with full control and visibility on all the
street lights. Not only does it offer the benefit of
automation to reduce labor costs but also digitalizes
the data improving maintenance needs for the future,
maximizing the street light uptime in a cost and
energy-efficient manner.
IV. IMPLEMENTATION
A. Experiment Design
In order to measure the performance of the
proposed solution, we are designed to build an IoT
application that can monitor the amount of daylight
surrounding a streetlight and turn the streetlight on
and off accordingly. This solution will allow
streetlights to come on when the sun is setting or if a
storm darkens the sky. It will also turn the lights off
at sunrise or when the storm has passed as proposed
in our system.
B. Challenges and Consideration
When developing an IoT application several
things should be taken into consideration. Security is
the top concern as there is no security standard for
IoT devices and applications. This leaves security
holes that can easily be exploited by hackers.
Technology inconsistency is another issue as there is
not a standard in place for how to develop IoT
applications. This leads to a fragmented market and
devices from different manufacturers not integrating
with each other.
The following attacks were evaluated against
common IoT device attacks. Our goal is to minimize
the risks from these attacks through the
implementation of security strategies, with adequate
protocol and filter methods to best control system
flow. Our security requirement concerns the
following list:
1) Transmission of abundant data processing
by IoT sensor
2) Configuration with virtualized environment
3) Centralizes the architecture
4) Secure communication channels in
preventing denial of service and spoofing
5) Firewall management of application
software and user privilege
C. Implementation Process
We start off by choosing a platform within
popular cloud providers such as Google’s Android
Things, or Microsoft’s Azure IoT Suite. These
platforms, and many others, are trying to solve the
security and inconsistent technology problems. Since
these platforms already have security implemented in
some layers, they are the best place to start. After
researching the different platforms to discover which
one suits the needs of the application the best, we
decided on utilizing Amazon AWS for its scalability
and reliability to host our proposed design. Hardware
was examined next, adequate research was performed
to ensure application reliability in terms of
connection stability and security. While the hardware
can either be built from scratch or purchased,
software simulations were of the hardware were
selected due to time constraints on the project
timeframe.
Knowing IoT devices are not useful if it is unable
to collect and report the data to the cloud, or if the
device is hacked or disabled by a bad actor. We kept
scalability in mind when designing the IoT
application to keep up with marketing demand in
terms of scalability. The applications need to make
fast real-time decisions based on the environment. If
the device cannot collect and report data quickly, or
the application cannot process and return a response
promptly, the consequences could be disastrous. For
example, a smart car cannot rapidly respond to a
pedestrian on the road, lives could be lost.
Again, security is our number one concern when
building the IoT system. Both hardware and software
security should be taken into consideration. Using
proven platforms and hardware vendors is the first
layer of defense as they will have basic security
measures in place. Encrypt and obfuscate all data sent
over the network to keep spies out of the data.
V. CONCLUSION
In this article, we design and evaluate a centralized
street light control mechanism through the use of IoT.
With scalability in mind, our proposed solution aims
to bring flexible applications to best optimize and
manage city street light systems to meet the needs of
the city. While one might argue high start-up costs to
implement such a system, the savings come in the
long run given the ability to administer city street
lights in an automatic, scalable, and maintainable
manner to bring public safety.
